job_title: Mail Clerk I in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: - None. Seriously, I cannot think of 1 redeeming experience I had working for Campus Mail.
cons:
- Awkward phone interview with like 6 people where everyone is talking over one another on speakerphone. Should've recognized this as a red flag but I didn't.
- They knew I was moving to the area and scheduled an in-person interview the day after I got here - my moving truck wasn't even unpacked. Also should've recognized this as a red flag but I didn't.
- I was extremely specific during the interview that I was taking this position expecting to be out every day at the same time and I was also expecting weekends and holidays off. Nobody disagreed. Day 1 I get told that I am going to be expected to work "mandatory overtime" of 6 days a week, 10-12 hours a day during the 6 week "move-in" period because they didn't have enough staff. Just...no. LOL.
- Slow computers, no modern technology. They have you taping receipts to paper and scanning them in using a photocopier. 
- I was gaslit and lied to by the Interim Director several times.
- You have to pay for your own parking. Yes, you have to pay them some of the salary they pay you to work there and it ain't cheap. Like $300/year.
- Hour-long lunches that unnecessarily keep you there. You can't leave because if you do you'll lose your parking spot and be parking on the other side of campus. Cut lunches to 30 minutes and let people leave 30 minutes earlier.
- Ultimately, they want you doing like 15 jobs under 1 title for $15/hour. And each of those 15 jobs has like 10 sub jobs. If you ever do work here, 99% of the people you work with will be new as in working there for <6 mos. They can't keep anybody.

review_title: nice campus, lucky to have a young, responsible and generous graduate advisor
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: People are quite layback and friendly on campus. A lot of free services are available for graduate students such as free academic writing consulting, dissertation writing workshops, and speed dating (just to name a few). They really try to make the graduate life fun and easier for you if you are willing to reach out.
cons: Too less invest in fundamental research such as math and physics. As a STEM field graduate, I feel marginalized from time to time. Being in the deep south, I experienced a few very rude encounters (all outside of campus though) in the past 6 years - people in other places would call this kind of rudeness 'racism', I guess. By the way, I am international.

review_title: Don't work here if you want to move up the employment ladder
pros: Flexible work schedule. You can take off just about whenever you need to, although as an hourly worker you don't get paid while your away. Management is usually laid back but sometimes without warning they will rage on the hourly workers, usually after they have been chewed out by someone above them.
cons: No pay raise in 2 years, despite minimum wage going up almost $1.50. Workload is unfairly distributed amongst people who are paid the same. We do really monotonous work, we do the same things over and over and over. Sometimes the work involves doing really pointless and senseless things that are extremely inefficient and you feel like you are not being used properly or efficiently and that you are being taken advantage of as an hourly worker. Benefits are terrible, there aren't any. You don't get a parking pass, no meal plan, and you have to walk about 20 minutes to work, rain or shine.

review_title: Rewarding & Fun place to work....great benefits....
pros: Benefits, atmosphere, ability to work with all departments and making lifetime friends, retirement, spring break & Christmas break off with pay (not part of vacation package), employee & dependend tution grant, many more pros
cons: "It's NOT WHAT you know....it's WHO you know".....many, many times.  Guidelines/Rules are NOT the same for entire university...depends on department.  Workload  is NOT destributed evenly among employees in same department.  Job title, pay & duties inconsistent within various departments.  Management, Supervisors, upper level executives within various departments not knowledgeable about employees job duties, processes, updated resources, etc.  Management, Supervisors, upper level executives and staff should be required to test in computer proficiency at least every 2 years.

review_title: Good benefits, low pay, career advancement is very slow to take place. Must pay for high-priced parking pass annually.
pros: Benefits were good and time off was decent. In time, it is possible to move from department to department, but don't be in a rush!
cons: Depends on the department in which you work...some people love it and others hate it. Low pay. Room for advancement within department--ASK about this prior to taking the job! Annual fee for parking pass is a bummer.

review_title: A stress free environment committed to working with students and their schedules
pros: Stress free atmosphere. They understand that we are students and have a full load of coursework in addition to our job. As such, they aren't very pushy or in your face. Most of the staff is also very friendly and welcoming to student workers, I feel like I am always being supported and encouraged.
cons: This is more of a campus issue itself rather than a specific issue with the job, but as stated prior, parking is not the best. It usually takes me 15-20 minutes to walk to work each morning. There is a CrimsonRide route that goes past the building where I work, but with all the stops the bus takes it generally takes the same amount of time to get there.

pros: I had an awesome advisor. Alabama has a ton of money, but isn't known for anything other than football. This means that you get to be in front of the line for a lot of cool toys. Low cost of living. I can't imagine grad school would be worth it anywhere else.
cons: COVID 19 has made it clear how the administration thinks about grad students. And it is that they don't. No clear path for conducting research on campus. Limited help for graduation. They threatened to fine people for parking on the faculty lot even though it was 5% full. Revoked building access with no plan for giving it back. COVID made things difficult, but the administration made things impossible at the slightest hint of trouble.

review_title: UA is a great place to work. Excellent holidays and benefit. Good colleagues and interesting work.
job_title: Local Area Network Coordinator in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Excellent holidays, leave times, and benefits. Interesting and challenging work usually on the cutting edge of research and field deployment of new systems.
cons: The salaries are significantly less than what one would expect from a private sector job and technology budgets are always a problem, but this is true pretty much anywhere one goes in the IT world.

pros: Flexible hours, reasonable management, nice colleagues, beautiful campus, and a satisfying sense of job security. I feel safe and comfortable in my job, and I truly love it.
cons: Both the university campus and the surrounding city are overcrowded, and the pay for this job is an insult. There are no benefits whatsoever because its not full-time. I am barely scraping by. You also have to pay for the privilege to park where you work. A parking pass for staff/faculty will run you about $300 per year. If you don't get one, you'll be ticketed.

review_title: Tutor at University of Alabama's Mathematics Technology Learning Center (MTLC)
pros: The MTLC hires undergrad students with significant math backgrounds (although a math major is not required) as tutors. Hours cap out at 20 per week. The work is not strenuous but not boring either. It's a great first time-tutoring job because there are instructors and grad students on staff who can answer your questions.
cons: I really have no complaints about the job. The work environment was the best I've ever had and I would still be working at the MTLC if I were still a student.

pros: The obvious answer might be the free on-campus housing and monthly stipend. But I have found that getting to be around great people is a better pro. The other RA's and Housing staff are fun to be around, especially when things get hairy. Satisfaction with residents will vary by hall and floor.
cons: So of course, being an RA you're going to be on call. There will be some terrible nights when residents are stupid drunk, or where you have to watch someone get arrested for drugs (hopefully not). Getting woken up in the middle of the night is never fun.

pros: Flexible Hours.  Getting Spring break off work and the week between Christmas and New Years off paid.
cons: No advancement for females unless you work in a department that consists of all women.  No Career path planning.  You get picked to be placed on projects without any input.  Men are advanced the quickest if they are married and especially if they have children.  Woman are completely overlooked-even if you have more experience.  The pay is substandard.

pros:
Tuition reimbursement for taking classes while employed. 
Tuscaloosa is a very affordable place town to live in (though not the most exciting for about 8 months of the year).
cons:
Little opportunity for career advancement or promotion when starting at a low level. 
Limited office budget for necessary travel and other expenses that would make the office more effective. 
Many Research Assistants employment policies do not qualify for the University's retirement fund matching policy. If that was in my benefits package, that would have been my number 1 "pro" because it is a great match policy.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Working as a student office assistant was a wonderful way to gain experience working in an office as a team while still being able to take a full load of classes. Hours were flexible and worked with my class schedule and my coworkers were pleasant people to be around. They even helped me prepare to find a permanent job once I graduate.
cons: Pay was low, and so were hours, but I understand that it was just a part time position and my primary focus was on classes anyway. There were no benefits (insurance, retirement, etc.) because it is a temporary position and office assistants are required to be students to hold the position.

pros: It offers employees a unique chance to get an inside view of the industry and trends, while working on real-life assignments. Although it is a student-run, non-profit agency, it is a great, great place to work (or serve as a glorified intern) pro-bono.
cons: Because it is a student run public relations firm at the university, there is little pay or perks in that area. It does offer many benefits, including a ton of experience, but no pay.

review_title: UA a good place to work...for the most part.
pros: Excellent benefits, excellent time off (great accrual of annual leave - decent sick leave accrual - holidays even spring break), overall environment is great...depending on the college/department.  Feel like part of something "bigger".
cons: Can become very much a "machine" in some areas.  Can be difficult to get hired on - when not as difficult, it does take a while for the process to be completed.  If you've applied for something, expect it to possibly take up to a month to hear anything after the job has closed from the jobline.  Salaries are not very competitive.

review_title: Supply Store Materials Clerk; Worked less than three months, and was terminated for not showing enough growth
pros: Benefits, generally easy work, most people are easy to get along with
cons: Sometimes hard work having to lift 100 lbs up stairs and in and out of vehicles with nothing more than a hand truck, will be reprimanded for things that aren't your fault, one particular individual talks down to everyone as well as curses at them and is impossible to please, I was fired with no reason other than I hadn't shown enough growth, and when I asked what the reason was I was told they couldn't give details and to call the individual I referred to previously and that individual ignored my call

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: You get your degree, the TA experience is good to be added to your resume, and in case you want to be a teacher later it is a plus! But I recommend it!
cons: Grading is difficult, you may not have enough time to work on your courses or other projects if you do so. But other than that, it is a good experience to mingle with undergrads!

pros:
Great schedule - They worked with my class schedule and the office was on campus, which is convenient .
Decent pay. You got paid on commission, so you got what you earned.
cons: Hard sell. Virtually no one buys print advertising anymore. This can also be seen as a positive if you can actually get results. AKA you can put on your resume that you were able to sell well in a dying industry.

review_title: Your GTA experience, and quality of life is  dependent on the  course instructors
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
The  students I teach
My research Group
cons:
University will only allow GTA's to be compensated for 20hr/wk even though the Job often requires twice that amount of time per week.

The time required to teach cause me to have to make a trade-off and either give up time fr Research, My school work, or Sleep.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Funding opportunities are fairly common that will cover tuition plus a decent stipend and health insurance. You just have to look for them. Also, plenty of funding in the grad school for travel to conferences.
cons: Depending on which department you are in, equipment and buildings can be outdated. Not as much of a problem for the new engineering buildings, but more common in some of the older ones.

review_title: Large load and low pay for graduate teaching assistants
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: The department in which I worked at UA, the English department, was a very positive and supportive community.
cons: The University requires graduate teaching assistants to teach 2-2 (on the heavy side of a teaching load for grad students) but pays less than comparable institutions and no longer offers health insurance. The health insurance stipend is insufficient for many students when paying for their own insurance.

job_title: Programmer Analyst, Senior in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
Nice physical environment (campus is beautiful)
For a while the work was interesting
Near total job security (if you like that kind of thing)
Decent benefits
cons:
Poor salary; advertised salary ranges are bogus; they basically lowball you
Forced to contribute to a long-term retirement plan that is only useful if you hang around for at least ten years
No money for people, lots of money for stuff (e.g. where I worked there was a roomful of unopened new computers, but staff were all underpaid)
Other staff were very cliquey (I worked there almost three years and despite numerous overtures I had lunch etc. with colleagues exactly ZERO times)

job_title: Office Associate II in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: I was definitely in my element working at The University of Alabama, since I had grown up in Tuscaloosa, my mother worked there for 32 years,and I am an alumna from UA, as well. Most of the employees at UA are very friendly and have no problem helping when necessary.
cons: As an office associate, it's very difficult, even with a degree, to be promoted to a different level position or even receive a decent salary without working there for 30 years.

review_title: Over a great place to work with top of the line benefits
pros: Number 1 for me is the benefits. There isn't another job in the state that I have researched that can be the benefits package you have here. The environment is also wonderful to to work in and around.
cons: I'll start this off by saying I am a staff(non-teaching) employee. It can be quite a mad house maintaining the external appearance and the new renovations and construction without disrupting either. And working around these students can be on occasion akin to herding cats.

job_title: Library Assistant II in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
vacation and sick time great
enjoy what I do
understand what is expected of me
currently enjoy co-workers but if you get a sour grape it can make it difficult
cons:
low moral
little support from Deans
too expensive to park with no guaranteed parking place 
enrollment has gotten so high that it is getting harder to keep up - have not hired enough support staff to keep up with enrollment
don't hire from within - have seen several good, qualified people overlooked for a job

pros: Get to enjoy artwork from different sources throughout the year. Very nice co workers and all Art Department Professors are awesome.  Interesting, even to non-Art students. Helped to learn art appreciation as a business student.
cons: Not enough hours allotted to work study students to make any good spending money (designated by govt, not University.) Not very many hours available for students to choose from.  It would be great if the University could pipe classical music through the sound system to create a better atmosphere for looking at art.

review_title: Good way to earn your Master's for free.
pros: Best part is that you get your tuition paid for, plus some money to live on. It's not much, but it's enough. Well, as long as you go half time. Quarter time will be cutting it pretty thin.
cons: I guess it would really just depend on the department you are in. I don't have anything negative to say about my experience as a graduate assistant.

pros:
Largest employer in the State of Alabama
Medical research is phenomenal and exposure to the professionals is wonderful
Good school
cons:
Takes along time to be included, not open to outsiders
Fake friendliness
Somewhat like being the unpopular kid in high school
It is easy to get promoted if you have completed all of your degrees at this university, i.e., BS, MS, PhD

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Great people to work with in a great environment that promotes growth. I enjoy the work I do there and I feel like I freedom to make my own decisions about my work.
cons: There really are not many cons that I can think of. One negative might be that the location is not the best. There really is not much to do in Tuscaloosa.

pros: I enjoy working with my coworkers--they all collaborate well. I also think there is a great balance of research and teaching (for those in academia).
cons: At times, it seems like the management is out-of-touch with what is happening a few levels below them. It is also located in Tuscaloosa. Coming from a larger city the town was a bit of an adjustment.

review_title: Working as an undergraduate research assistant was a great learning experience, but the pay was low.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: I made a meaningful contribution to an important project and made a little bit of extra money. My schedule was very flexible and I had no problems working while attending classes.
cons: I know that I was just an undergraduate research assistant, but the pay was pretty bad. I made more per hour in high school than I did working for the University. My lab could've used some equipment upgrades as well.

pros: You get to do your homework, meet new people, and exercise your customer service skills daily. Working at Burke you get to meet incoming Freshman looking into traditional dorms and give tours while exercising your communication skills. Overall this job is a great "dressing room" for jobs after graduating college.
cons: The cons are that as a student employee, you are only allowed to work 20 hours max, and while making minimum wage its not the ideal income for a college student with financial struggles.

review_title: Working for the University of Alabama College of Arts and Sciences' Office of the Dean
pros:
- Flexible work hours and decent wages
- Time off as needed
- Networking opportunities within the administration of the College of Arts and Sciences and other Offices and Departments
- Personal interaction with the Dean, Associate Deans, professors, and other administrative employees
- Time to complete college course homework and assignments
cons:
- Temporary/Part-time employment
- Minimal challenge, monotonous work, limited promotion opportunities
- No real responsibility or influence over office operations
- Difficult and exacting superiors

pros: Great People, Friendly, Helpful. The university seems to care about their employees and the benefits of working here is great.
cons: Parking is a huge issue. You have to park a long distance away and maybe catch the bus the rest of way unless you pay over $300-400 each year for a staff pass.

pros: Paid vacation and sick leave with lots of paid holiday time for hourly employees. Decent medial insurance. Pretty campus. Great educational benefits for employees and their families. Getting spring break off is quite nice.
cons: High cost for limited parking. Generally low salary. No pay distinction given for hourly employees for having more than high school diploma.

pros:
•Free housing
•Lots of interaction with other people
•You develop good friends
•You gain a lot of experience working in uncommon conditions.
cons:
•You can't move off campus
•Training can get very redundant
•Having to be the rule enforcers can earn you a bad rap with some of the residents

job_title: IT Student Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: It was a really easy student job, even when they had work for you to do, it was easily done in a couple minutes. You could use the rest of the time to do hw.
cons: Utterly boring and soul sucking. Sometimes they can not even give you the proper software keys you need to do the work they assign you.

pros: Great employer with flexible hours for students. Pay is good and supervisors are excellent and very eager to help not only as employers but also through professional development. Tuscaloosa is a great city with lots of options for a college student. One could not ask for a better experience in a college job.
cons: Lower wages than one could get working somewhere else, but after all it is a student job so the flexibility makes up for the lower pay.

pros:
Stable job on campus
Work isn't difficult
The people are fun to work with
Gain some work experience before graduation
cons:
Pay is low
Gamedays can make working on campus impossible
Not much room for advancement in student jobs
Work can be boring at times

review_title: Working a state job was a fairly laid back environment but still interesting
pros: Working with the athletic department gives you interesting opportunities with one of the most powerful collegiate sports organizations in the country, the campus and facilities are beautiful, the atmosphere is generally pretty good, and they often promote/hire from within
cons: Living in a college town could be rough for older employees, the athletic department gets very hectic during football season, and kind of slow the rest of the year

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
Appropriate Workload - The administration is aware of your studies and scales your workload accordingly
Direct Interaction with Students - As a Master's student, you are encouraged to teach, dealing with students in a classroom environment.
cons: Rigid hour cap - If you do happen to exceed the maximum number of allotted work hours, you do not receive additional compensation.

pros:
-Management is amazing
-Lots of flexibility to work in what you are good at
-Good pay for an on-campus job
cons:
-You need to be able to work in the evenings generally; not very much flexibility in hours for most people
-Might not be able to pull as many hours as you want, although there is generally 12+

pros: Good overall community of faculty and staff, pretty good benefits, HR has always been helpful, lots of resources. Nice looking campus. Well run, compared to other higher ed I've dealt with. Administration genuinely want to improve campus every year.
cons: Resources, work culture and competence will vary a lot by department. Some jobs will be highly dependent on student workers with high turnover year to year. Many times the bureaucracy moves like molasses.

job_title: Organic Chemistry Postdoctoral in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: The chemistry department here is really good.  People here are really nice and easy to work with.  They have  360, 500, and 600 MHz NMRs.
cons: It gets hot outside in the summer.  It also rains a lot.  There football team loses on occasion, but not often.

review_title: Worked at UA for a few years
job_title: Event Manager-Arts and Sciences in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Great benefits, good insurance, nice town
cons: Low pay, doesn't matter how much previous experience they give you the minimum usually, terrible management in my department and HR doesn't help, try to get you to do five jobs at once

pros: I applied to this job through the UA student jobs listing online, the hours were very flexible, with your class schedule. The job itself is boring but you can get a good amount of studying done while working.
cons: Only minimum wage, and its hard to get enough hours to actually more than $200 a week.

review_title: Job that got me through college
job_title: Senior PHP Developer in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
- Decent pay (paid higher than most other student workers), but mostly due to workload and expectations.
- Flexible hours
- Academics were priority
cons:
- Not paid as much as a typical web dev (I was still in college, not much of a surprise).
- No benefits (again, college student, not to be expected)

pros: Depending on who you work with, working for the University of Alabama can be a great experience. You have ample opportunity to make important decision and work through with it.
cons: The university is a great place to work; however, there some downsides to working here and this is a function of the person you work with. Some bosses are so hard and fastidious such that no matter what you do they are not satisfied.

pros: The people are typically great to work with.  School spirit is huge and everywhere, which is great for work-life balance.  The people really make it fun.
cons: Pay is often among the lowest in the field.  Parking can be a nightmare.  Being a large university, it's sometimes hard to do things departmentally because of required oversight.

job_title: Student Program Director in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Great academic opportunities, ability to impact students' lives, flexible work schedule and understanding management, always extended opportunities to get training for better leadership
cons: Tuscaloosa is a college town, not much to do here. The culture is very southern, so it may be an adjustment for those not accustomed to it.

pros: Peers are very considerate and easy-going.  Great benefits with the Alabama Retirement System. Some people complain about parking and traffic, but I don't find it overbearing.
cons:
It's academia, so the pay is lower than in the corporate world. 
Being around college students all day can be a pro or a con depending on how you look at it.

review_title: Working for housing can be rewarding, but it's also horrible.
pros: You get to work with students and really make a difference in their lives. It's neat seeing them grow.
cons: Housing and Residential Communities is an unorganized organization. RAs are told about big events last minute, and upper management typically does not care about the RAs working for them.

review_title: A lot of opportunities for students
pros: Working on campus is very convenient for students. Hours are very flexible and the workload is very manageable. Depending on the supervisor, there can be a lot of flexibility.
cons: You won't make a fortune and different departments can be run very differently. What you learn in one job probably will not carry over to another job. A fair number of people are doing their job for the first time.

pros:
Some of the best co-workers you could ask for.
Great support group from the university itself.
Professional development was not lacking and a major driver for advancement in the university.
cons: Some red tape when it comes to the politics that can come from a large state run institution in the south. Had a tendency to shy away from change because "we have always done it that way" was the mentality at times.

review_title: Need to get with the times
pros: The students are engaged and bright. The faculty are generally collegial and helpful
cons: The pay here is considerably less than the national average. They feel this is justified given the cost of living in Tuscaloosa but it's not that much less expensive than other areas.

pros: It is a family atmosphere, rich in tradition and worthy of anyone to come work. I work hard because I want to.
cons: It always seems like the University is looking for new ways to increase revenue, even at the expense of others.

review_title: A good place to learn how to be prepared for another job in the future.
pros: Great benefits, fun people to work with, free (or inexpensive) tickets to sporting events, nice winters, great facilities, flexible hours
cons: pay to park, no free lunch, very hot summers, bad management, poor planning, not a lot of vision for future

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: First of all, The University of Alabama is a great research University. Secondly, The University of Alabama  has a plenty of nice and helpful advisors. Thirdly, Tuscaloosa is a nice town, I enjoy the life there.
cons: First of all, the public transportation in Tuscaloosa is not very good, a car is needed. Secondly, there always traffic jam in the university area. Third, for a civil student, the career opportunities are limited.

job_title: Graduate Teaching/Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Very good preparation for my field. The facilities were up to date and the managers of the instruments were very knowledgeable.
cons: The graduate school does not seem that different from other universities, so the only con I could mention would be to have more more TAs become RAs on a grant.

pros: Everyone works good hours, and hardly worked any weekends.  The management is very friendly and easy to work for.  They have a relaxed dress code.
cons: The pay was minimum wage for a student part-time job, with no chance of a pay increase while you are there.

review_title: Big Organization with perks and benefits
job_title: Graduate Community Director in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
- Assistantship paid for my tuition, provided housing, and a great stipend
- Very flexible around my school schedule 
- Coworkers are fun and motivated
- Benefits including: healthcare plan and gym membership
- Always trying to advance you as a professional
cons:
- In such a large organization, you feel small and meaningless sometimes
- Hard to get to know everyone
- Large organization means a lot of bureaucracy and red tape

pros: Very friendly people, easy to get along with. Everyone understands the importance of football season! The office atmosphere is very alive. Honestly, if it weren't for the wonderful people I work with, I'd be searching for another job.
cons: Low pay (barely above minimum wage), so work often feels undervalued. Parking is a mess on campus, but I'm not sure how much my management can do about that.

pros: This is the best company I have worked with. They are the most caring individuals, and it really is a family. You grow to know all of the staff and faculty in a short time and are able to grow connections and peers among different ages of colleagues.
cons: I do not have any cons for the University

pros: Beautiful campus, nice co-workers, great graduate students; flexible teaching opportunities
cons: Consumer culture where students are king; Pay is low for adjuncts but also for tenure track faculty; Very hierarchical, lack of shared governance within departments; confusing expectations regarding tenure and promotion;

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: People here are super nice. Students greet you when they see you. The work environment is not intense at all and people have reasonable expectations for timeline to get things done.
cons: There are not much cultural events going on in town. Students don't have very high academic outlook.

job_title: Student Recruitment Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: You get to work with the sweetest people you'll ever meet, especially Cheryl. The work keeps you busy and is a great experience builder for someone who couldn't get an internship.
cons: Nothing at all. The people are great and so is the job.

pros: Benfits, Time Off, Great People
cons:
Salary, but some of that is made up for in benefits,
Don't expect well defined policies and procedures

review_title: Great company to work for in college
pros:
Great Networking with skybox holders
Big tips from the skybox holders 
Feel valued by managers
cons: You miss out on game day tailgating and that is the basic premise of attending Alabama during Fall season. the hourly salary could be a little higher for working 8+ each game.

pros: Depending on your department, UA has some good graduate funding, especially considering the cost of living in Tuscaloosa. Opportunities for teaching experience abound.
cons: The health insurance that comes with a GTA position does not cover a lot, and does not include dental or vision. GTAs (and adjuncts) are also underpaid considering the actual amount of work that they do, though this issue isn't exclusive to UA.

pros: Great work atmosphere centrally located in the southeast. Of course football dominates the social scene, but the opportunities at the university are great.
cons: The university can nickel-and-dime faculty for parking and building fees. Teaching workloads can be high with little show of appreciation.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: -Fully funded during graduate studies, received access to University amenities, received legal/professional training
cons: -parking for on the job work was very difficult and employees need to buy a very expensive parking pass in order to park

review_title: I have had a fabulous time here and made many connections with many influential people.
pros: It is a student job so the job gives me time to work on homework as wel as what I am expected to accomplish on the job.
cons: There are no "Cons" that I can think of, working at The University of Alabama is one of the best jobs I have ever had.

review_title: Roll Tide! The University of Alabama offers an excellent work environment with many enjoyable opportunities.
pros: Highly educated co-workers and a fun working environment with excellent challenges.
cons: The bureaucracy around getting things accomplished, especially in the arena of salaries can be frustrating to deal with.

job_title: Administrative Office Specialist Ll in Birmingham, AL
pros: If wanting to pursue another career that requires you to go to school, you can go to UAB for free. If your immediate family member wishes to go to UAB (college) then 50% of their tuition is covered. I think that's great. Plus there are other advantages, but too many to name.
cons: You will never receive a Christmas bonus or anything.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: I work at the Institute for Social Science on campus and one of the biggest pros is the people I get to interact with.
cons: One big negative about this job (being a research assistant) is being expected to work and answer emails/texts 24/7. While my schedule is flexible, I'm expected to be almost on call whenever they need me to do something.

pros: Work schedule flexibility, ability to access all resources in the lab that I work in, ability to assist faculty and students with their projects
cons: Organization of the lab could improve, besides that, the prototyping lab is a great place to work. I would recommend

review_title: Low pay with low cost of living
pros: Low cost of living, Southern hospitality, Good weather
cons: Low pay, live pay check to paycheck, nothing much to do in Tuscaloosa

pros: A wonderful group of people, and each department has its own specialty. Most of these people are very spirited about their jobs and want to help others in any way.
cons: I didn't get a pay raise until my last semester of working. Your job duties are treated like they don't really matter much.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros:
Work with a highly motivated and creative group of individuals who value working hard, a balanced life, and professional growth. A generous time-off and benefits policy is in place. 

Offered real world experience in my field of study while paying tuition for graduate school and a stipend for living expenses.
cons: Parking, as with most Universities, is adequate, but not stellar.

pros: Great people, wonderful facilities and the best students one could ever hope for. I would return in a heartbeat.
cons: Tuscaloosa, AL is the hottest location in the world, with temperatures regularly reaching 102 degrees during the summer.

review_title: A Great place to learn and work
pros: Nice environment, Great People, Fun Facilities, 2 days a month vacation, Amazing Medical
cons: Much lower then national average pay, loss of employees due to lower pay, No further compensation

job_title: IT Technical Specialist III in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Flexible with scheduling, ample time off with school breaks and vacation + Sick time earned, great support staff to get things done in a decent amount of time.
cons:
Lower wages than private sector but you come here for the benefits, not to get rich.

Everything around the UA moves at a snails pace when it comes to hiring.

job_title: Traffic and Programming Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: Great health insurance and access to the Teachers Retirement System of Alabama
cons: In my experience, the biggest negative was poor upper management. The management at UA value flattery and politicking over actual experience and hard work. This resulted in both upper and lower management being unqualified. Meanwhile, non-management employees are passed over for raises  and expected to take up the slack from their under preforming supervisors.

pros: Close to campus. $150 stipend. Perfect for those who need some cash and a place to stay.
cons: Long nights when you are on call. Some buildings can have less than awesome residents. Just be respectful and you'll be fine.

review_title: Great environment fostered by incredible people
pros: UA provides opportunities for students to get work experience without having to sacrifice time for classes. All in all, UA provides much more than education through the classroom. The faculty and staff here want us as students to grow in as many ways possible.
cons: There is not always a lot of work to do.

pros: Great work environment with room to grow.  Education benefits.  Being a part of tradition that strives for perfection.
cons: Parking issues.  Traffic congestion and construction currently are a nuisance.  Older buildings are in need of upgrade.

review_title: I love working as a grad assistant at UA.
job_title: University of Alabama Grad Assistant in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: The schooling is paid for. This is a huge advantage. Also, you get to teach undergrad classes which gives you extra experience.
cons: You don't really make a lot of money. Also, there is no summer opportunity for my program, so you only have a job for 9 months of the year.

job_title: Online Tech Support in Tuscaloosa, AL
pros: I really love my coworkers and being a full time student, having the ability to do some of my homework while on the clock is awesome as well
cons: The pay sucks. Especially when it gets busy during the beginning of the semester and also the end. Also, the university doesn’t offer paid holidays to its student workers

pros: Faculty is unusually collaborative and helpful.  Genuinely felt like a family.  Numerous internal grants and programs to further professional development.  Relatively generous conference funding.  Great library.
cons: Living in Tuscaloosa as a single, 30-something is less than ideal.

pros: I just worked in a lab as an assistant. The work was a good resume boost and I liked the people that I worked with.
cons: There wasn't really anything that I didn't like other than working by myself some days. It gets boring when you don't have anyone to talk to while you are doing something repetitive.

review_title: The University of Alabama is getting better every day.  Roll Tide!
pros: Lots of friendly people, supportive management, and opportunity to succeed.
cons: Could definitely improve its LGBT related employment benefits.  There is often a difference between the employees who started pre-2002 and those who started after.

pros: The department was filled with ok employees, but with little to no drive. Management was nice and accommodating, and plenty of vacation time.
cons: the pay is very low compared to other IT jobs, and the path to moving up is based pretty much purely on time worked.

pros: Been employed here for over 25 years. First 15 were great. Work to staff ratio was sufficient.
cons:
Depending on are you are in, there often is not enough work to do but you are necessary because desks need to be covered. 
Cost to park is too high.
Benefits are not as good as they once were.

pros: I work with colleagues who provide support and a pleasant working environment. Additionally, I have flexibility and support to pursue scholastic endeavors that allow me to grow as a professional.
cons: Birmingham lacks diversity compared to other cities I have lived in but it is certainly growing and can truly see myself living here.

review_title: Free Room, With little work required
pros: I go to school here to & get to live/ work in a dorm right across from all of my classes! Great education!
